Title: June 2015
Content: PMT  19 An exhibit in a science museum requires the observer to use a pump to create air bubbles in a column of liquid. The bubbles then rise through the liquid.  (a) (1) Complete the free-body force diagram for a bubble as it rises through the liquid. (3)  *(11) It is observed that larger bubbles reach the top of the column of liquid in less time than smaller bubbles.  By considering the forces acting on a bubble as it rises, explain this observation.  (3)  21  Ti

Title: June 2015
Content: PMT  (11) The photographs are at a scale of 1 to 12. By using measurements from the photographs, calculate the speed of bubble B between photographs 2 and 3.  (c) A student wishes to determine the total drag force acting on a bubble.  (1) Explain why it might not be possible to use Stokes  law to calculate the drag force acting on a bubble.  23  Ti
